 TOGETHER WITH

Edmunds <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Mk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628&lp=logo> 
Good morning. Yes, summer is for checking another national park off the list, dancing at weddings, and sipping High Noons on a lakeside dock. But, if you’re looking to upgrade your business skills in between Cornhole showdowns, check out our Business Essentials Accelerator. You’ll learn the Xs and Os of what makes companies tick and meet some pretty great people.

Get the details and apply here <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6MW?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>—the four-week course begins on June 5 and requires just a five-hour weekly commitment.

—Matty Merritt, Cassandra Cassidy, Molly Liebergall, Abby Rubenstein, Neal Freyman

Markets: Stocks surged <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6MX?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> after both President Biden and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy expressed confidence that a debt ceiling deal to prevent a US default would happen soon (though some nervous Democrats are reportedly still pushing for other possible solutions <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6MY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>).

Stock spotlight: WeWork, a company that’s no stranger to unpredictable CEOs, plunged on the surprise announcement that its current leader, Sandeep Mathrani, will soon step down.

 

EDUCATION

Another company goes after FL’s ‘anti-woke’ agenda <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6MZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> Books disappearing from bookshelf <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6MZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> Francis Scialabba
Publisher Penguin Random House and advocacy group PEN America sued <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6M-?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> a Florida school district yesterday over book bans, joining Disney in pushing back against the state’s “anti-woke” policies that critics say censor free speech and infringe on civil rights.

The details: PEN America, Penguin, and five authors of banned books filed a federal lawsuit against the Escambia County School District and School Board, claiming they violated the First Amendment by banning 10 books from its school libraries. The suit also alleges the groups violated the constitutional equal protection clause because most of the books targeted included themes of race, sexuality, or gender.

A number of books including George M. Johnson’s All Boys Aren’t Blue, Toni Morrison’s The Bluest Eye, and Judy Blume’s Forever… were challenged by one single language arts teacher, according to the suit. And it claims that despite a review committee ruling the books were OK for young readers, the school board still removed them. The lawsuit wants the banned books back in libraries. Escambia County School District has declined to comment.

What’s so special about Escambia County’s book bans? PEN America said this specific school district has attempted to ban or restrict almost 200 books.

It’s also in Florida…

...which has been churning out laws restricting what educators can say and teach, including at the collegiate level <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6M_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>. Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis, who is widely expected to run for president, signed four bills limiting LGBTQ+ rights yesterday, one of which expanded the so-called “Don’t Say Gay” law to prohibit teachers from discussing gender or sexual orientation with students through eighth grade (up from third grade).

That’s the law at the center of the bitter dispute between Disney and DeSantis. Disney, one of the biggest private employers in Florida, criticized the legislation and has sued DeSantis over what it called an “anti-business, and patently unconstitutional” effort by the governor to punish Disney for its criticism.

Looking ahead…it remains to be seen whether DeSantis’s spat with Disney and his broader “anti-woke” agenda will be popular among voters as he gears up to run for president. He took an L this week when Jacksonville, the largest city in Florida, elected a Democrat <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N0?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> as its next mayor over DeSantis’s candidate.—MM

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N1?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N2?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N3?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> 

TOGETHER WITH EDMUNDS

Drivin’ some serious value <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Mk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628&lp=title> Edmunds <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Mk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628&lp=image>
Demand for used cars is hiiigh, with the average trade-in value in April 2023 being 80% higher than it was just 4 years ago.

Wondering what you can get for your car? Edmunds’ free online appraisal tool <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Mk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628&lp=text1> gives you an accurate valuation in a flash. And while you’re looking at its potential value, you can even get a no-obligation offer for your car from a dealer. Talk about a one-stop shop.

In the market for a new set of wheels? Edmunds also helps you browse vehicles and make an informed purchase.

Oh, and if you’re going electric, you can use Edmunds’ EV incentives page <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Mm?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628&lp=text2>—just search by model to find electric vehicles in your area that qualify for tax credits, rebates, and more $avings.

Start your engines <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Mk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628&lp=text3>.



WORLD

Tour de headlines TikTok lock ban bad Francis Scialabba
Montana bans TikTok. Republican Gov. Greg Gianforte signed a law that makes Montana the first US state <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> to comprehensively ban the Chinese-owned app. While other states have banned TikTok on government-issued devices over national security concerns, Montana’s law blocks the app from operating inside its borders and penalizes app stores from making TikTok available for download in Montana. The ban goes into effect on Jan. 1, but you can bet opponents (like TikTok and free speech advocates) will take Montana to court over this major escalation.

Things are about to get heated. The World Meteorological Organization estimates <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> that there’s a 66% chance the world will experience warming of 1.5 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels, at least temporarily, by 2027. The number has long been considered a breaking point for keeping climate change in check. The group expects that the extra heat from the natural El Niño weather phenomenon coupled with human-caused warming will likely make the next five years the hottest on record.

Uber to let teens ride. To expand its user base, Uber is preparing to take on one of the most thankless parenting tasks: ferrying teens around. The dominant ride-hailing company will now permit unaccompanied teens <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> aged 13+ to use the service, though initially only in certain cities. They’ll have to use new teen accounts attached to family profiles that will summon only “experienced and highly rated drivers” and will allow their parents to track rides in real time, Uber says.

MEDIA

Harry and Meghan say they were chased through NYC <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N7?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> Harry and Meghan say they were chased through NYC <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N7?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> MEGA/Getty Images
Prince Harry, Meghan Markle, and Markle’s mom were involved in a “near catastrophic car chase at the hands of a ring of highly aggressive paparazzi” for over two hours on Tuesday night after leaving a gala in New York City, according to the couple’s spokesperson. As the news hit yesterday morning, everyone was reminded of the paparazzi chase that Harry blames for the death of his mother, Princess Diana.

But police painted a different picture <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N8?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> than the “near catastrophic” episode described by Harry and Meghan. The NYPD said that there were no collisions or injuries reported, while police sources told ABC that the amount of paparazzi involved was not at the levels described by the couple’s spokesperson.

At one point in the night, the couple got into a taxi. The driver didn’t feel threatened by the photographers: He told the Washington Post <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6N9?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> that his passengers “were quiet and seemed scared, but it’s New York—it’s safe.”

Prince Harry versus the tabloids

This isn’t the only tangle Harry has going on with the tabloids. He and Meghan are actively involved in three lawsuits against newspapers in the UK, alleging unlawful information gathering via phone hacking.

And Harry is serious about controlling the narrative: He’s expected to testify in court next month. The last time a senior member of the royal family appeared in court was in 1891, when Edward VII served as a witness to an alleged card-cheating scandal.—CC

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Na?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6NB?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nc?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>

FOOD TECH

CRISPR lettuce for your summer salad <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nd?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> Scientists at Pairwise have gene-edited mustard greens to be less bitter <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nd?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> Hannah Minn
Genetically edited mustard greens are coming for the salad base throne thanks to scientists who have figured out how to remove the trait that makes the nutritious vegetable taste so bitter.

The new and improved milder mustard greens from agriculture startup Pairwise will be the first food on the US market to have been tweaked using the revolutionary gene-editing tool CRISPR. The modified greens are already being served in a few restaurants and will begin hitting grocery stores this summer.

But you probably won’t know they’re anything special from the packaging. Unlike GMO foods that bend the laws of nature by incorporating genes from other species, gene-edited foods contain modified versions of their own genes, so the USDA doesn’t require the “bioengineered” label it slaps on GMOs.

The logic is that gene-editing merely speeds up a process that can occur naturally: Rather than using the centuries-old crossbreeding methods that can take a decade to alter traits, scientists used CRISPR to directly edit the mustard greens DNA for debittered lettuce in just four years, according to Wired <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Ne?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>.

New priorities: Until recently, gene editing and genetic modification had been used mainly to boost crop yields. Mustard greens 2.0 is all about getting consumers to substitute iceberg and other nutrient-lacking lettuce for a more nutritional vegetable.—ML

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nf?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6NC?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nh?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>

GRAB BAG

Key performance indicators Strippers protesting for union rights at The Star Garden in Los Angeles FREDERIC J. BROWN/AFP via Getty Images
Stat: Dancers at LA’s Star Garden Topless Dive Bar may become the only unionized <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Ni?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> strippers in the US. An official union vote count is scheduled for today after the club’s management agreed to stop opposing it, leaving the dancers poised to join the 51,000-member Actors’ Equity Association. During their 15-month effort to unionize, the dancers brought attention to their cause with colorful protest themes like “twerking-class heroes” and “dress as your club’s OSHA violation.”

Quote: “Unfortunately, the lack of generational wealth/seed capital from ethically bankrupt sources left me unable to weather the quiet winter season.”

Running a small business is hard, and running an avowed anti-capitalist one is probably even harder. The Anarchist, a Toronto coffee shop that opened in March 2022 and billed itself as an “anti-capitalist, anti-colonial cafe, shop, and radical community space on stolen land,” plans to close <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nj?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> at the end of the month. Its owner said the anti-capitalist cafe suffered from the most capitalist of headaches: not bringing in enough cash.

Read: How TikTok took over the menu and made everything cheesier, saucier, and covered with caviar. (Grub Street <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>)

NEWS

What else is brewing
F1’s Emilia Romagna Grand Prix <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nl?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>, scheduled to take place in Imola, Italy, this weekend, has been canceled after heavy rain and flooding led to at least eight deaths and the evacuation of 5,000 people in the area.

Target <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nm?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> says it expects its losses from organized retail crime to spike by $500 million this year.

Elizabeth Holmes <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Nn?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> has been ordered to report to prison on May 30 after an appeals court denied her bid to stay out of jail while she challenges her conviction for defrauding Theranos’s investors.

Google <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6No?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628> plans to start deleting inactive accounts, so if you’ve got one you haven’t used in two years but want to hang onto, now’s the time to log in.

Perdue <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Np?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31517464.2876628>, which is known for selling chicken, is getting into the beer business, specifically the business of selling cans of limited edition “Beer Can Chicken Beer” for shoving inside poultry.

Three headlines and a lie

Three of these headlines are real and one is faker than the phrase “made with real fruit flavor.” Can you spot the odd one out?

 TOGETHER WITH

The Ascent <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6E6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432&lp=logo> 
Good morning. Hey, here’s one less thing to worry about: There’s virtually no possibility a large asteroid will hit Earth and wipe us all out <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Kk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> within the next 1,000 years, according to a new study accepted by The Astronomical Journal. Now we can return to our baseline existential dread of figuring out what to make for dinner.

—Cassandra Cassidy, Matty Merritt, Abby Rubenstein, Neal Freyman

*Stock data as of market close, cryptocurrency data as of 1:00am ET. Here's what these numbers mean. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/s1?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>

Markets: Stocks took a hit from disappointing retail sales data and, you’re never going to believe this, ongoing concerns about smashing through the debt ceiling. However, Capital One got a boost <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K3?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> after Warren Buffett said it’s in his wallet. Buffett’s conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway, has taken a nearly $1 billion stake in the bank, according to a Tuesday filing.

Debt ceiling update: Progress, maybe? After more negotiations, GOP House Speaker Kevin McCarthy said a deal to raise the debit limit was “possible <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Ka?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>” by the end of the week, while President Biden is leaving his upcoming trip to Asia earlier than planned to push through an agreement.

 

TECH

AI is in its regulation era <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Sam Altman at Senate hearing <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Win McNamee/Getty Images
Typically when a tech CEO goes in front of a Senate committee, they end up explaining how to use email. Not so yesterday, when Sam Altman, CEO of ChatGPT-maker OpenAI, testified <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> on Capitol Hill on the future of AI and how the field should be regulated.

What happened at the hearing? Setting an ominous tone for what was to come, Sen. Richard Blumenthal, the chair of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Privacy, read opening remarks that he later revealed were created by AI. The hearing continued with a discussion of the dangers presented by an unpredictable, evolving technology that can create and spread misleading information without us even realizing it (looking at you, drippy pope).

Lawmakers acknowledged past failures to implement timely regulation for advances in technology. Sen. Blumenthal said, “Congress failed to meet the moment on social media,” and hinted at wanting to avoid the same mistake again.

Regulating AI is like herding kittens on rollerskates Experts don’t agree on what regulation <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> should look like for AI because it’s evolving much faster than other technologies. And moving quickly (or at all) isn’t exactly Congress’s strong suit, so it’s unclear whether traditional lawmaking can keep up with the regulation of a technology that is constantly changing.

But they’ll try. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer is working alongside experts to create a framework that focuses on transparency within AI models. It would require that models disclose who trained them and their data sources, but the proposal will likely face resistance from AI companies.

Altman, who warned “if this technology goes wrong, it can go quite wrong,” is also in favor of regulation—but came with his own ideas. He advocated for the creation of a new government agency with the power to license large AI models, create and monitor safety standards, and conduct independent audits. But he did not mention requiring transparency around model training or source data.

Looking ahead…expect the regulation talk to heat up as both Congress and tech leaders try to figure out how to manage the existential risk posed by AI.—CC

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K7?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K8?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6K9?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> 

TOGETHER WITH THE ASCENT

It’s like a reward <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6E6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432&lp=title> The Ascent <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6E6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432&lp=image>
Cha-ching. That’s the sound of your credit card rewards hitting your account. And if you love to hear that jangle, we’ve got just the card for you.

This credit card <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6E6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432&lp=text1> is packed with benefits like unlimited cash rewards on purchases and a sweet $200 welcome bonus (after you spend $500 within 3 months).

Need more perks? No problem. This card <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6E6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432&lp=text2> is packed with them, making it a reward-seeker’s dream.

No wonder The Ascent’s independent team of experts calls it one of the best all-around cards.

Rack up the rewards <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6E6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432&lp=text3>.



WORLD

Tour de headlines Victor Wembanyama on the basketball court Catherine Steenkeste/Getty Images
San Antonio won the Victor Wembanyama sweepstakes. The Spurs were victorious <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Kb?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> in the 2023 NBA Draft lottery, meaning they’ll have the right to select French basketball phenom Victor Wembanyama, who’s regarded as the best NBA prospect since LeBron James. Wenbanyama combines a 7-foot-5 frame with skills no player of his height should have, like smooth handles and a 3-point-shot. The two times the Spurs had the No. 1 pick in the draft, they chose well, selecting all-time players David Robinson (1987) and Tim Duncan (1997).

Tesla will begin advertising. After shunning <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Kc?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> marketing spend for its entire existence, the automaker will join…virtually every other automaker in hawking its cars to you via ads. “We’ll try a little advertising, and see how it goes,” CEO Elon Musk said at the company’s annual shareholders meeting. Musk also teased two new vehicle models and, in an interview <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Kd?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> with CNBC, boasted that he’s “the reason that OpenAI exists” due to his past investment and involvement with the skyrocketing Chat-GPT creator.

​​The Covid home improvement boom is officially over. So says Home Depot, which posted a revenue drop in the first quarter and warned that annual sales would decline in 2023 for the first time in 14 years. Home Depot said that shoppers are now holding off <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Ke?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> on the big-ticket purchases they made during the pandemic and were choosing to break up larger projects—like remodeling a bathroom—into smaller, bite-sized pieces.

TECH

Your iPhone is getting a new voice: yours <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Siri talking <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Francis Scialabba
A new feature <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> debuting this year for Apple devices will allow you to create a digital version of your own voice to use to speak with anyone you’d like.

The Personal Voice feature is one of several forthcoming accessibility features that Apple unveiled yesterday. It’s meant to aid people with conditions such as ALS that put them at risk of losing their ability to speak.

Apple promises that after spending just 15 minutes reading text prompts into an iPhone or iPad, your digital voice will be ready to go. Another new feature, Live Speech, will let a device read messages you type.

But…what’s to prevent someone from stealing your voice like Ursula the sea witch? In a world where AI can produce a “Drake” bop <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> and perhaps extend Tom Hanks's acting career long after his death (according to Tom Hanks <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FG?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>), it’s reasonable to be concerned about facilitating deepfakes of yourself. But Apple claims the feature will rely on “on-device machine learning to ensure user privacy,” so your voice won’t be waiting in the cloud for hackers.—AR

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FH?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FI?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FJ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>

Defend your data: Cyberthreats are on the rise. Is your org protected? Join AWS’ webinar to learn data recovery best practices <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/4DE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432&lp=text1> and modern data protection strategies from AWS Native and AWS Partner customers. Register now <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/4DE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432&lp=text2>.



FOOD & BEV

Taco Bell wants to free T*co T*esday <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FS?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Taco out of open cage <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FS?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> Francis Scialabba
Normally the villain of your insides, Taco Bell is trying to be a hero by freeing the name “Taco Tuesday” from its IP prison. The fast-food chain filed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FT?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> a petition yesterday to cancel the trademark of the phrase owned by a smaller taco chain, Taco John’s.

Taco John’s, maker of the also-trademarked Potato Olés, has owned the trademark on Taco Tuesday in 49 states since 1989 and has not been shy about sending cease-and-desist letters to anyone who tries to use it to promote tacos…on Tuesday.

In the one state where Taco John’s doesn’t have the trademark—New Jersey—a restaurant and bar called Gregory’s owns it. Taco Bell filed to Baja blast away Gregory’s trademark as well.

The creators of the Crunchwrap Supreme (also trademarked) said in a press release that the phrase “should belong to all who make, sell, eat and celebrate tacos”—so it won’t be seeking damages or future trademarking of the phrase on its own. In response, Taco John’s announced…a Taco Tuesday deal.

Could Taco Bell win this thing? In 2019, LeBron James tried to trademark Taco Tuesday, and the US Patent and Trademark Office rejected his app, saying that the phrase was just too common (thereby kind of admitting no company should hold a trademark on it). Taco Bell might be hoping this precedent will work in its favor, but it will likely be a couple years until the beef is resolved.—MM

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FU?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FV?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FW?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>

GRAB BAG

Key performance indicators The Rock saying The Fate of the Furious/Universal Pictures via Giphy
Stat: In the 1980s and 1990s, almost one-third of job seekers in the US would pack up and move for a new role. Now, virtually nobody is doing that <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FX?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>. According to a new survey from Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the share of American job seekers who relocated for a new position dropped to a record low of 1.6% in Q1 of 2023. The ability to work remotely, combined with the fact that finding a new house right now is the absolute worst <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>, is responsible for the seismic change.

Quote: “I was ready to give up 6 hours in.”

Good thing Nigerian chef Hilda Effiong Bassey held strong, because she may have just set a new world record by cooking for 100 consecutive hours <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Kj?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>—from last Thursday until Monday. In an interview with CNN, Bassey said she was motivated to finish her slow-cooking marathon to showcase Nigerian cuisine to the world. Her efforts elevated her to a quasi-national hero, even earning the praise of Nigeria’s president.

Read: The long, strange history of the baseball cap. (MLB <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>)

NEWS

What else is brewing
The FTC <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FK?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> sued to block Amgen from buying Horizon Therapeutics for $27.8 billion. It’s the first time in more than 10 years that the agency has tried to block a major pharma merger, per Axios.

The DOJ <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FL?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> charged a former Apple employee with stealing autonomous vehicle trade secrets for a Chinese company. It’s part of the Biden administration’s new crackdown <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FM?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> on tech espionage.

Hey, BlackRock employees <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FN?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>: You’ve got to go to the office at least four days a week starting in September.

The Cannes Film Festival <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FO?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> opened with Jeanne du Barry, a French period drama starring Johnny Depp in his first major film since the Amber Heard defamation trial.

ABC <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6FP?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> said it’s moving forward with its long-awaited senior citizen season of The Bachelor.



RECS

Wednesday to-do list
For the logistics nerds: This website <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Kf?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432> allows you to visualize almost every US company’s supply chain.

Draw my professor: Here’s what Midjourney thinks professors look like <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Kg?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31505854.2881432>, based on their department.

 TOGETHER WITH

Virtuix <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=logo> 
Good morning. Yesterday, Sports Illustrated announced that 81-year-old Martha Stewart will appear on one of the covers of this year’s Swimsuit Issue, making her the oldest SI Swimsuit cover model ever. Between this and hard-launching Pete Davidson’s current relationship, Stewart is having a productive 2023.

Fun fact: Which model did Stewart dethrone as the oldest SI cover star? Maye Musk, who appeared on last year’s cover at age 74. Yes, that’s Elon Musk’s mom.

—Cassandra Cassidy, Molly Liebergall, Sam Klebanov, Abby Rubenstein, Neal Freyman

Markets: Stocks climbed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BS?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> slightly, with the Dow finally breaking a five day losing streak as investors keep an eye on Washington, hoping that debt ceiling talks will yield a breakthrough. News out of the capital yesterday wasn’t good for H&R Block or TurboTax parent Intuit: They fell after the IRS announced a plan to let people file their own taxes digitally— for free.

 

ECONOMY

Ballooning consumer debt isn’t deflating <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BT?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Credit card that is being blown up with a bike pump <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BT?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Hannah Minn
If you’ve been dropping plastic a lot and hoping it’ll take care of itself later, join the club. Yesterday, the New York Fed released its Q1 report on household debt: Findings include a record-high debt level of $17 trillion, persistent credit card debt, and rising delinquency rates.

A typical first quarter sees credit card balances decline as people pay off what they spent over the holidays while trying to out-gift their in-laws. But, for the first time in 20 years, that isn’t the case, according to Bloomberg. Balances remained flat over Q1, suggesting that people aren’t cutting back and are probably using credit cards to finance daily spending due to the rising cost of…pretty much everything.

It’s not just that credit card balances are flat. Delinquency is rising, as is its intimidating older brother, serious delinquency, which is when a debt is 90+ days past due. The Fed’s report showed that 4.57% of credit card debt transitioned to serious delinquency last quarter, up from 3.04% in Q1 of 2022. And for credit card holders aged 18–29, 8.3% of balances were in serious delinquency.

Plastic isn’t the only thing to blame In addition to causing lots of folks to check their credit card balance real quick, the report had a few key takeaways:

Auto loan delinquencies are higher than they were before the pandemic for those under 40. The average monthly car payment is $729.

Mortgage debt increased by $121 billion in the first quarter, reaching a $12.04 trillion balance, likely as a result of the Fed’s rate increase extravaganza.

Student debt saw a slight decrease in the rate of serious delinquency, which went down to less than 1%—but that’s probably because repayment is paused for now.

Zoom out: Debt balances are almost $3 trillion higher than pre-pandemic, but Fed analysts see an upside; many households are still more financially stable than they were before thanks to the mortgage refi boom <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BU?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> of 2020–2021 when rates were at their lowest.—CC

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BV?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BW?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BX?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> 

TOGETHER WITH VIRTUIX

Invest in the ultimate power-up for gamers <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=title> Virtuix <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=image>
The ultimate gaming power-up isn’t gold coins or the ability to see through dungeon walls. It’s realism—that feeling that you are inside the game.

And that’s just what Virtuix <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=text1> has done with their omnidirectional VR gaming treadmill: the Omni One <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=text2>. It’s designed to fit in your living room *and* offer unrestricted freedom of movement.

Sounds next level, right? Yep, but let’s one-up things. You can invest in Virtuix’s game-changing VR treadmill today <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=text3> (and join Mark Cuban and other prominent investors).

Virtuix has already raised over $35m. And if you add to that by investing just $1k, you’ll get 30% off your very own Omni One treadmill. That’s a $780 value.

Let’s recap: Invest $1k in Virtuix and save 780 bucks on your very own Omni One, but only until May 18. Invest here <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=text4>.



WORLD

Tour de headlines Illustration of a Call of Duty skeleton with Microsoft logo in his eyes Illustration: Dianna “Mick” McDougall, Photo: Call of Duty/Activision
At least the EU likes Microsoft’s $69b deal to buy Activision. In a win Microsoft needed to keep its deal with Activision alive, EU antitrust regulators gave its efforts to acquire the Call of Duty-maker the green light <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> yesterday. But Microsoft still has an uphill battle to get the deal through antitrust watchdogs in the UK and the US. UK regulators rejected the deal last month, and yesterday criticized the fixes accepted by its EU counterpart. And in the States, the FTC has sued to block it.

FBI comes under fire for Trump-Russia probe. Trump-appointed Special Counsel John Durham has finally released <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> his report on the agency’s probe into allegations linking former President Donald Trump’s 2016 campaign to Russia, and he concluded that the investigation should never have happened. The 306-page report states that the agency rushed into the investigation based on “raw, unanalyzed, and uncorroborated intelligence,” while being much more cautious regarding claims against Hillary Clinton. The report is unlikely to end partisan fighting over the issue, especially since Durham’s four years of work yielded few court victories.

Vice Media filed for bankruptcy. The company, which was valued at $5.7 billion in 2017, filed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Co?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday and plans to sell itself to a group of creditors for $225 million. It’s the latest in a string of digital media companies to stumble recently after advertising revenue became harder to come by. Vice’s filing was also one of seven large companies to head to bankruptcy court in a 48 hour period—marking the largest number of filings during a two-day period since 2008, according to Bloomberg.

TECHNOLOGY

OpenAI founder dreams big about more than AI <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6B-?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Sam Altman leaving car <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6B-?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Sean Gallup/Getty Images
There’s a lot brewing with OpenAI founder Sam Altman besides ChatGPT as he comes for Elon Musk’s No. 1 billionaire-innovator spot. He’s about to secure <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6B_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> a $100 million funding round for an eye scan-enabled global cryptocurrency, worldcoin, according to the Financial Times.

It’s not totally unrelated to his signature project: Worldcoin’s goal is to verify whether users are human by scanning their irises to disburse universal basic income...to workers displaced by AI.

Finding investors for a crypto startup during crypto winter is just one of Altman’s side projects. The venture capitalist’s resume increasingly looks like a cyberpunk manga.

The Altman-backed nuclear fission startup, Helion Energy, recently notched a deal to supply electricity to Microsoft in 2028, even though most experts say that timeline for making the tech work is a long shot.

But so is expanding the average human lifespan by 10 years, a research effort by Retro Biosciences, which the serial entrepreneur plugged with $180 million.

Zoom out: This may all sound like the beginning of a dystopian sci-fi scenario, but Altman claims he’s aware of the potential dangers of his ventures and is concerned with more than just profit. Still, some worry that he won’t be able to build technology at a breakneck pace without unleashing chaos.—SK

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C0?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C1?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C2?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> 

TOGETHER WITH STARBUCKS

Starbucks <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=image>
Sip on a little something joyful. The Starbucks Frappuccino coffees you know and love are going Mini. Find your favorite Frappuccino coffee flavors, now in a perfectly sized 6.5-ounce can <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=text1>. Treat yourself to a Mini can of creamy Caramel or smooth White Chocolate Mocha deliciousness. Your coffee craving is calling <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6BE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431&lp=text2>.



TECH

Trade offer: You get a free TV, Telly gets your eyeballs <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C3?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Trade offer: You get a free TV, Telly gets your eyeballs <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C3?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> Telly
Whoever has been making sacrifices to the free television gods just got their prayers answered. The hardware startup Telly is giving away 500,000 55-inch 4K flat-screens at no cost to your wallet.

But, like most free things, the TV comes with a catch <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C4?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>: constant advertisements and data collection.

A never-ending ad stream will live on the dual-screen TV’s lower “Smart Screen,” a nine-inch addendum that can also show weather, stocks, and other widgets. The main screen might also display ads when you’re not using it.

You’ll also have to answer some demographic and psychographic questions when you sign up to make the ads more targeted: “If Toyota wants to run an ad to people that currently own a Honda whose lease expires within the next 12 months, we pick and choose those individual TVs,” Telly co-founder Ilya Pozin, who also co-founded Pluto TV, told <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C5?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> the Hollywood Reporter.

If you’re okay with all that, you can reserve a free TV on Telly’s website <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C6?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>. They’re expected to ship this summer.

Zoom out: Marketers say it was only a matter of time before a free TV emerged, since prices for devices like Roku and smart TV sets have been coming down as ad sales have grown. Ad spending for internet-connected TVs rose from about $6 billion in 2019 to more than $21 billion in 2022, according to Statista.—ML

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C7?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C8?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6C9?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>

GRAB BAG

Key performance indicators An image from the Netflix show Queen Cleopatra Queen Cleopatra/Netflix
Stat: Netflix’s Queen Cleopatra was in the streamer’s top 10 television show yesterday, but any success came in spite of the show’s audience score on Rotten Tomatoes. The series, which debuted last week, had a 1% audience <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Ca?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> score over the weekend before ticking up to 2% yesterday with 2,500+ reviews in (by contrast, the Elizabeth Taylor version blamed for destroying multiple marriages has a 68% audience score). But the barrage of negative reviews likely stems as much from the backlash against the casting of a Black British woman as the iconic Egyptian queen as from anything to do with the Jada Pinkett Smith-produced series—though its score from professional critics is only 11%.

Quote: “The thing that I miss the most about being on the surface is literally the sun.”

University of South Florida Joseph Dituri, who also goes by Dr. Deep Sea, recently beat the world record <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Cb?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> for time spent living underwater without depressurization by spending 74 days 30 feet deep in a Key Largo lagoon inside the Jules’ Undersea Lodge. And he’s not about to surface any time soon—he plans to spend 100 days there to complete his research. But despite ascribing to the philosophy that it’s better down where it’s wetter, Dituri admitted he misses seeing the sun rise. He doesn’t miss class, though—he’s still teaching online.

Read: The greatest wealth transfer in history is here, with familiar (rich) winners. (New York Times <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Cc?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431>)

NEWS

What else is brewing
President Biden <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Cd?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> is expected to meet with House Speaker Kevin McCarthy and other lawmakers today to resume debt ceiling negotiations as a possible default nears.

Two staffers <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Cp?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> were attacked at the office of Rep. Gerry Connolly, a Virgina Democrat, by a man wielding a baseball bat.

Turkey’s election <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Ce?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> is officially too close to call, though its leader of 20 years, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, was ahead in the voting. A runoff vote is scheduled for May 28. A candidate needs to get more than 50% of votes to win.

Elon Musk <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Cf?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> owns Twitter, but he still can’t say whatever he wants there: A federal appeals court rejected his bid to overturn his settlement with the SEC requiring a lawyer to review his Tesla-related tweets before he posts. In other legal news, Musk was subpoenaed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Cg?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> by the Virgin Islands as part of a Jeffery Epstein sex-trafficking lawsuit.

Chocolate milk <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6Ch?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31491786.2900431> may come off the menu when the USDA finalizes new guidelines for school lunches, the WSJ reports.

 TOGETHER WITH

Facet <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uU?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=logo>

*Stock data as of market close, cryptocurrency data as of 12:00am ET. Here's what these numbers mean. <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/s1?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>

Markets: Despite the risk of the US defaulting on its debts next month, equity investors have kept calm and carried on <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6ww?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>, sending the Nasdaq to a weekly gain last week. But over in the bond market, investors are sweating. The cost of credit-default swaps, which act as insurance over a default, is higher in the US than in emerging markets like Mexico and Brazil.

Stock spotlight: This is just a wild stat about the stock market’s concentration…Apple’s market cap is now greater <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wx?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> than the value of every company in the Russell 2000 small-cap index combined.

 

GEOGRAPHY

The suburbs are buzzing <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> Suburban mall in Virginia <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> Robert Knopes/Education Images/Universal Images Group via Getty Images
Have a few morning meetings, hit a Sweetgreen for lunch, finish up work, then go see your favorite band play a show—sounds like a day you could only pull off in a city.

Not anymore. As Axios reported, the rise of remote work has breathed new life <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wz?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> into America’s suburbs, drowning out the roar of leaf blowers with commercial growth, an influx of new residents, and increased cultural opportunities, like legitimately good restaurants <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wA?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>.

Retailers show the way

You’ve read headlines about major retailers closing stores in downtowns. But the reverse is happening in the suburbs, where retailers are opening new locations <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wB?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> to meet customers where they live and, increasingly, work. The availability of urban retail topped suburban availability in the second half of last year for the first time since at least 2013, the WSJ reported citing CBRE data.

Case study: Sweetgreen.

In 2019, 35% of Sweetgreen’s real estate footprint was in the suburbs.

As of last summer, half of its locations are rockin’ the suburbs.

Even suburban malls, which have been given their last rites for decades, appear to be recuperating. Shopping center landlords are setting leasing and occupancy records this year, according to the WSJ.

A trickle into a flood

The US suburban population had been increasing before the pandemic, growing 10.5% between 2010 and 2020, according to the Census. But lawns and patios became even more attractive during Covid, and the desire to live your best North Caldwell life has stuck around post-pandemic. Nearly half of millennials surveyed in a recent Bank of America report <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wC?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> (43%–45%) said they expected to buy a house in the suburbs.

And as the suburbs have ballooned, they look a lot less like Leave It to Beaver. The populations of big American suburbs are now more diverse <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wD?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> than the broader US population, according to Brookings.

Bottom line: The WFH-enabled rise of the suburbs may serve as a wake-up call <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> to cities, where, in the case of NYC, 26 Empire State Buildings’-worth of office space now sits empty. According to Stanford’s Nicholas Bloom, the typical office worker is spending $2,000–$4,600 less annually in city centers.

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wG?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wH?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> 

TOGETHER WITH FACET

The first step to facing your financial fears <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uV?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=title> Facet <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uV?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=image>
What do we do when we’re stressed out? We procrastinate, of course. Because nothing solves a problem like avoiding it!

Jokes aside, *90% of Americans are anxious about money <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uW?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=text1> (yowza ). Luckily, Facet’s Financial Wellness Quiz <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uX?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=text2> is just the thing to nudge you out of fear and into empowerment. Best of all, it’s totally free.

Facet’s Financial Wellness Quiz is quick and easy. In just 5 minutes, you’ll have your personal score and insights into 5 key areas of your financial life. Time for a clearer picture…and a sigh of relief.

One small step for you, one giant leap for finance-kind. Complete the quiz to get your deets <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=text3>.



WORLD

Tour de headlines Campaign posters of the 13th Presidential candidate and Republican People's Party (CHP) Chairman Kemal Klçdarolu (L) and the President of the Republic of Turkey and Justice Development Party (AKP) President Recep Tayyip Erdoan (R) are seen displayed Tunahan Turhan/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images
​​ Turkish election is headed for a runoff. In the country’s most consequential election in a generation, neither the authoritarian-leaning incumbent, President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, nor his challenger Kemal Kilicdaroglu eclipsed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wI?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> the 50% threshold needed for victory, so the two men will likely square off in a runoff scheduled for May 28. If it’s anything like yesterday’s first round, it will be tense: Both candidates said the others’ vote counts were not to be trusted.

Sweden wins Eurovision. The Eurovision-obsessed country took home the top prize with Loreen’s performance of the power ballad “Tattoo <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wJ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>.” An estimated 160+ million people tuned into the famously over-the-top singing event, which took place in Liverpool, England, on behalf of last year’s winner, Ukraine (the show featured numerous tributes to Ukraine). Sweden’s win means it’ll host next year’s competition on the 50th anniversary of the most iconic Eurovision performance of all time: ABBA singing “Waterloo.”

Ja Morant suspended again. The Memphis Grizzlies star has been suspended <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wK?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> from all team activities after he appeared to be holding a gun on an Instagram livestream this weekend. It’s the second time in just over two months that Morant was suspended for seeming to hold a gun in a social media video. After the first incident, in March, Morant was suspended for eight games and lost out on $668,000 of his salary. When returning from that suspension, Morant said he sought counseling to help him better deal with stress.

SPORTS

5 sports betting stats on its 5th birthday <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wL?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> a roulette wheel inside a baseball diamond <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wL?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> Francis Scialabba
Five years ago yesterday, the Supreme Court lifted <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wM?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> a federal ban on sports gambling in the US, spawning a multibillion-dollar industry that’s transformed how Americans watch, talk about, and experience sports.

We plucked five numbers from the sports betting world to highlight five years of legalization.

$95 billion: That’s how much Americans bet on sports in legal jurisdictions with consumer protections last year, Sportico reported. It’s more money <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wN?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> than the amount spent on ride sharing, coffee, and streaming.

71%: Two sports betting companies, DraftKings and FanDuel, control more than 70% <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wO?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> of the US market, per gambling analytics firm Eilers & Krejcik. But despite taking in ~10% of wagers, these companies have struggled to turn a profit. FanDuel recorded its first quarterly profit last year, and DraftKings has yet to report a profitable quarter.

33: That’s the number of states, not including Washington, DC, that currently have legal sports betting. Another four states have legalized sports wagering, but don’t have any sportsbooks operating yet.

3: The three most-populous US states—California, Texas, and Florida—have not legalized sports gambling. They account for 26% of all teams in the major North American pro leagues, according to Axios.

45%: The number of women joining sportsbook apps jumped 45% last year, marking the third straight year that new women users exceeded men. Plus, the amount bet on women’s sports in 2022 increased 61% annually on DraftKings.

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wP?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wQ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>   <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wR?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> 

TOGETHER WITH THINK!

Think! <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6b8?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=image>
The full picture of health. Building your health isn’t about how many miles you run or pounds you lift. It also involves your mental and emotional state—so we partnered with think! to create a calendar of 28 tips <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6b8?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=text1> to build mental and emotional strength. Start today <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6b8?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301&lp=text2>.



CALENDAR

The week ahead US President Joe Biden meets with US Speaker of the House Kevin McCarthy and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer in the Oval Office Demetrius Freeman/The Washington Post via Getty Images
Debt ceiling talks resume. President Biden and GOP leaders will continue <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wS?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> negotiations on raising the debt ceiling early this week. Biden said the talks were “moving along,” and the structure <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wT?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> of the deal is starting to emerge, according to the FT. It will involve capping government spending in some form.

Cannes Film Festival: Truckloads of rosé will be consumed during the 76th Cannes Film Festival in southern France, which begins tomorrow <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wU?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>. If you go, you’ll catch new films from Wes Anderson and Martin Scorcese, but don’t try to protest: The region’s government has banned all types of demonstrations amid heightened tensions over France raising the retirement age.

Lots of sportsball: The NBA (curse you, Sixers) and NHL will begin their conference finals series, the Preakness Stakes will be run in Baltimore, and the PGA Championship will tee off at Oak Hill in Rochester, NY.

Everything else…

Walmart and Target highlight a busy week for retail earnings.

The 11th installment of the Fast & Furious franchise, Fast X, will hit US theaters on Friday. Many vehicles were harmed in the making of this film.

The Bitcoin 2023 Conference returns to Miami, a one-time crypto haven that has mostly moved on <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wV?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>.

GRAB BAG

Key performance indicators Snapchat influencer Caryn Marjorie cutiecaryn via Snapchat
Stat: Snapchat influencer Caryn Marjorie made more than $71,000 <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wW?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> in one week after releasing an AI version of herself, CarynAI, and charging fans $1 per minute for CarynAI to be their virtual girlfriend, Fortune reported. As of last week, CarynAI had more than 1,000 boyfriends (aka paying subscribers) and Marjorie estimates she could eventually bring in $5 million/month from her chatbot.

Quote: “I do not understand what is happening but I am incomprehensibly grateful to bigolas dickolas.”

It’s quite reasonable that writer Amal El-Mohtar doesn’t understand what is happening, because it is strange. A book she co-authored in 2019, This is How You Lose the Time War, has shot up <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wX?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> to the top 10 on Amazon’s bestseller list thanks to a tweet by an account called Bigolas Dickolas Wolfwood. Last Sunday, Bigolas implored his followers to go buy this novella, writing, “read this. DO NOT look up anything about it. just read it.” The post went mega-viral and now the lives of everyone involved have changed forever.

Read: Notes from Prince Harry’s (and Andre Agassi’s, and Phil Knight’s) ghost writer. (New Yorker <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wY?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301>)

NEWS

What else is brewing
Yesterday <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6wZ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> marked one year since 10 people were killed in a racist attack on a Buffalo supermarket. President Biden marked the anniversary by publishing an opinion piece <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6w-?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> in USA Today calling on Congress to enact gun reform.

US border crossings <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6w_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> fell by 50% after Title 42 ended—the opposite of the spike that was expected, Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas said.

Argentina <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6x0?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> will raise its benchmark interest rate by 600 basis points to 97% today as part of emergency measures its government is taking to stabilize runaway inflation.

A Sherpa guide <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6x1?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31480644.2876301> summited Mount Everest for the 26th time, tying the all-time record.

  BROWSING

  Classifieds banner image <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uk?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> The wackiest headlines from the week as they would appear in a Classifieds section.

Careers

OSCAR WINNER HIRING BABYSITTER: At age 79, Robert De Niro revealed <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6ul?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> that he had fathered his seventh child (his oldest child is now 51). De Niro is excited to have the opportunity to force one more generation to watch Goodfellas in his lifetime.

MUSIC LIQUIDATOR: Spotify purged <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6um?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> thousands of AI-generated songs uploaded by the music startup Boomy. The streamer said it flagged the tunes it thought were being listened to by bots, which inflated listener numbers. But maybe it was just bots making music for other bots 
  SNAPSHOT

  Photo of the week Brienz, Switzerland I, Parpan05, Brienz-Brinzauls Dorf, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/legalcode> Take a good look at the Swiss village of Brienz…because it may be the last time you see it intact. Residents of the picturesque town had to evacuate <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uu?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> their homes last week after officials warned that 70 million cubic feet of rock could break off the nearby mountain and come crashing down on Brienz in the coming days or weeks.

  SCIENCE

  Dept. of Progress Dexter from Dexter's lab saying Dexter’s Laboratory/Warner Bros. Domestic Television via Giphy Here are some illuminating scientific discoveries from the week to help you live better and maybe even win over your neighbor’s cat.

The financial dangers of looking on the sunny side. Spring is here, the sun is shining—and new research shows that’s likely to affect the stock market. A study <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uv?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> that examined the weather’s impact on Chinese investors’ behavior in auction-style secondary equity offerings found that on days investors needed sunglasses, they were more optimistic and less risk-averse, driving bidding up and discounts down. Even one standard deviation in either sunshine intensity or duration made a noticeable difference. This adds to previous studies that found sunlight is associated with higher market returns and that fall and winter IPOs get priced lower.

Learn how to catcall more effectively. Cats are notoriously fickle, but French scientists have determined the best way to call <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uw?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> an unfamiliar cat to you and actually get it to come is by using a combination of audio and visual cues (rather than just one or the other). If you have to pick just one, a purely visual summoning gets a quicker feline response than a solely vocal one. The researchers discovered all this by testing out techniques on kitties from a cat cafe.

Get ready for Smell-O-Vision. One quick way to tell whether you’re in a VR simulation or the real world is to ask yourself whether things have scents. But that might change now that scientists have developed more efficient systems for integrating smell <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6ux?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> into the virtual world. Previous efforts involved messy aerosols and bulked-up headsets, but the new scent delivery method works by heating wax, so the user needs just a small under-nose patch or soft mask. The researchers have made 30 smells so far, including stinky durian fruit, and testers identifying them had a 93% success rate.—AR



 

FROM THE CREW

The Crew <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5pF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781&lp=image>
Improving internal morale: When Valimail Chief People Officer Elaine Mak saw employee engagement was down, she partnered with CFO Ryan McQueeney <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5pF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781&lp=text1> to align their talent needs and financial goals with the larger organizational strategy. Read more from CFO Brew <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/5pF?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781&lp=text2> on how this approach can be implemented by finance leaders to improve employee retention.


  NEWS ANALYSIS

  How tech CEOs learned to hate remote work <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> Zuckerberg over zoom with office window in background <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uy?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781>Michael M. Santiago/New York Times Staff/Getty Images Can you guess what “one of the tech industry’s worst mistakes <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6u_?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781>” is, according to OpenAI CEO Sam Altman?

It’s not Quibi. It’s buying into the idea that 100% remote work wouldn’t cost startups creativity, as he recently said at an event organized by payment company Stripe.

The OpenAI CEO is the latest tech exec to argue that an 8:57am wake-up call and leisurely cold brew in bed might not be the optimal Tuesday morning routine for tech workers, despite many leaders having once hailed WFH as the way of the future.

Then vs. now

When the pandemic shut down the world, many tech leaders were quick to proclaim a permanent WFH revolution. But now, one after another, Silicon Valley bosses are trading remote work evangelism for remote work frustration, citing productivity concerns.

Here are a few examples.

Meta: In May 2020, Mark Zuckerberg told The Verge <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6v0?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> he wanted to mold Facebook into “the most forward-leaning company on remote work at our scale.” In the first months of the pandemic, he said employees could apply to make their job permanently remote and predicted that half of the company could work off-site in 5–10 years.

Fast forward to 2023: Zuck is saying that in-person engineers “get more done” and that Meta is reevaluating its distributed team approach.

Salesforce: In 2021, Salesforce’s CEO Marc Benioff was seemingly at peace with the idea of never again seeing his company’s glitzy SF skyscraper bustling with workers. “They’re mostly at home, and that’s fine,” he said then.

Now, it might not be fine after all: Late last year, he wondered in an internal Slack if the “much lower productivity” of employees hired during the pandemic is “a reflection of our office policy,” according to CNBC.

What changed?

The US is experiencing the biggest decline in worker productivity since 1948, according to research from EY-Parthenon, and many executives have been quick to single out remote work as the main culprit.

This is what they cite to prove their point.

* A study <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uA?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> published in Nature Human Behaviour found that working remotely made Microsoft’s remote workers miss important learning opportunities by not rubbing elbows with coworkers who aren’t part of their immediate team.

* More recent research <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uB?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> showed that interacting through a screen can make workers less likely to generate ideas. That’s a problem for tech companies needing to out-innovate the competition.

For many industry leaders, accessing a wider talent pool outside of traditional tech hubs isn’t enough to make up for those drawbacks. And as widespread labor shortages subside and layoffs sweep through Silicon Valley, companies are no longer in a perk war to recruit and retain the brightest minds.

Zoom out: The Big Tech office push mirrors broader white-collar labor market dynamics. In December, 13% of LinkedIn postings were for remote jobs, compared to 20% nine months prior.—SK

<https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uC?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781>  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6v1?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781>  <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uE?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781>

  DESTINATIONS

  Place to be: Milwaukee’s haunted hotel Pfister Hotel on September 20, 2014 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin Raymond Boyd/Getty Images It’s a big universe out there. In this section, we’ll teleport you to an interesting location—and hopefully give you travel ideas in the process.

Los Angeles Dodgers star outfielder Mookie Betts isn’t spooked by a 100 mph fastball…but he sure as heck is scared of ghosts.

When his team traveled to Milwaukee last week to play the Brewers, Betts declined <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uO?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> to stay at the downtown Pfister Hotel with the rest of the Dodgers and opted to shack up with some friends at an Airbnb instead.

Why? Because the 130-year-old Pfister Hotel is allegedly haunted by the apparition of its founder, Charles Pfister. And, while it’s unclear whether Pfister’s ghost is on the Brewers payroll (designated specter?), he’s relished the opportunity to disturb visiting baseball players who’ve stayed there.

* In 2001, visiting player Adrián Beltré said his TV inexplicably kept turning off and on, and he heard unexplained knocking on his door, according to Sports Illustrated. He ended up getting just two hours of sleep in three nights.

* Eight MLB players, including Bryce Harper and Giancarlo Stanton, reported spooky experiences <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uP?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781> when staying at the Pfister. “From the minute I walk in there, I’m freaked out,” Justin Upton told ESPN.

When its founder isn’t conducting psychological warfare against baseball players, the Pfister Hotel is considered one of the nicest hotels in Milwaukee and a historic landmark <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6uQ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31465963.3277781>. Every US president since William McKinley has stayed at the Pfister, and Elvis Presley checked in just four months before he died, according to WUWM.—NF

  COMMUNITY

  Crowd work Last week we asked: You’ve been chosen to give the commencement speech at a prestigious university. What’s the absolute worst piece of advice you could give the graduates?

Here are our favorites:

* “Don’t wear sunscreen.”—Sarah from San Jose, CA

* “Hiring managers love it when you ask the interviewer what THEIR biggest weakness is.”—Darlene from Hofstra University

* “Keep all of your finances a secret from your loved ones.”—Cate from WV

* “By all means, obsess over the mistakes you have made so far in your life.”—Janyce from Omaha, NE

* “Don’t have a quarter-life crisis and start working in national parks.”—Nicole from Glacier National Park, MT

* “Always volunteer to help move. Your back will thank you.”—Brian from Brooklyn, NY

This week’s question

What is the ultimate summer ingredient to add to a dish (or a drink)?

Matty’s answer to get the juices flowing: “Berries. Summer is for slapping a berry compote onto some pound cake, throwing some raspberries in a cocktail, and eating blackberries by the truckload.”

 SPONSORED BY

Remi <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6tQ?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31470502.99558&lp=logo> 
Good morning. The Social Security Administration released its list of the most popular baby names for 2022, and Liam and Olivia continued their reigns as the top names for boys and girls, respectively.

But look at the fastest-rising names, and you’ll see the impact of pop culture. Dutton, popularized in the TV Western Yellowstone, moved up the most spots of any name, jumping 986 spots from 2021 to No. 835 this year.

Hopefully the Duttons will fare better than all the poor Khaleesis out there.

—Matty Merritt, Sam Klebanov, Cassandra Cassidy, Neal Freyman, Abby Rubenstein

Markets: Stocks tumbled yesterday as regional banks continued to look iffy and new data showed consumer sentiment dropping, pushing the Dow and S&P 500 to their second straight weeks of losses <https://links.morningbrew.com/c/6vR?mid=7cd3d7efcb2b5d1a6cbe0bf0931f4b2f&cid=31470502.99558>.
